prompt: A 69-year-old man was evaluated in the neurology clinic of this hospital because of progressively worsening ataxia. The patient had been well until 9 years before this evaluation, when abnormal gait and impaired coordination developed. He was unable to walk in a straight line; he bumped into walls when walking down a hallway. He also had difficulty reading traffic signs while driving and noted a change in the quality of his voice. The patient was evaluated at the neurology clinic of another hospital and began physical therapy. During the next several years, symptoms gradually worsened despite physical therapy. The patient was no longer able to drive or play golf, and he intermittently used a walker because of unsteadiness. He had frequent falls, including one that led to fractures in six ribs. His speech changes worsened, such that he could no longer sing. The patient was referred to the neurology clinic of this hospital for evaluation. In the neurology clinic, the patient reported frequent bowel movements, approximately 10 per day. He had no vertigo, lightheadedness, hearing loss, tremor, erectile dysfunction, disturbance of sleep, or urinary incontinence. He reported a sense of visual disorientation with head movement and with changes in the direction of gaze. He had a history of hyperlipidemia. Medications included atorvastatin, cetirizine, and a multivitamin; there were no known drug allergies. The patient had recently moved from an urban area in the southeastern United States to a suburban area of New England. He drank one glass of wine nightly; additional alcohol use caused worsening of ataxia and dysarthria. He had previously smoked five cigarettes daily but had quit smoking 30 years before this evaluation; he did not use illicit drugs. The patient’s mother had died of heart failure at an elderly age, and his father had died after a stroke and myocardial infarction at 70 years of age. The patient had two adult children, who were healthy. His two brothers and one of his sisters had celiac disease; the sister also reportedly had a shuffling gait. The sister’s daughter had received a diagnosis of Turner’s syndrome and had been seen by a neurologist for a balance disturbance. A brother’s grandson also had celiac disease and a gait disturbance (Figure 1). Family History.Shown is a representation of the patient’s family history obtained at presentation. The black square with the arrow indicates the patient. Shading indicates family members with a balance or gait disorder. Slashes indicate deceased family members. The temperature was 36.6°C, the blood pressure 136/88 mm Hg, and the pulse 72 beats per minute. The patient was alert, oriented, and attentive and provided a detailed history. He had moderate dysarthria, with impairment in the rate, rhythm, and clarity of speech. An oculomotor examination revealed complete and conjugate gaze in all directions; he had intact smooth pursuit movements but had slow, dysmetric saccades. Results of a head impulse test were abnormal, with corrective saccades noted bilaterally. Normal tone and full strength were present in all major muscle groups of the arms and legs. Reflexes were 2+ and symmetric at the knees but absent at the ankles. Plantar responses were flexor bilaterally. Rapid tapping of the index fingers on the thumbs was dysrhythmic and uncoordinated. Finger–nose–finger testing revealed mild intention tremor. Heel-to-shin testing revealed symmetric jerking movements with lateral movements across the shins. Vibration and joint-position senses in the legs were profoundly decreased: the patient was unable to sense vibration at the toes, had a decreased ability to sense vibration at the knees, and had difficulty discerning the position of his big toe with his eyes closed. There was sway in his stance, regardless of whether his eyes were open, and he could not stand with the feet together. The patient walked without support. He had a wide-based gait with considerable staggering and jerky, stiff movements of the legs. He was unable to maintain balance in a tandem stance or to walk with a tandem gait. The complete blood count and blood levels of electrolytes were normal, as were test results for kidney, liver, and thyroid function; antibodies to thyroid peroxidase and thyroglobulin were not detected. Blood levels of cyanocobalamin, methylmalonic acid, vitamin E, and glycated hemoglobin were normal; anti–glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies and tissue transglutaminase antibodies were not detected. Results of serum protein electrophoresis were normal. Genetic testing revealed no mutations in genes associated with spinocerebellar ataxia types 1, 2, 3, 6, and 8. Clinical testing of otolith function revealed abnormal vestibular-evoked myogenic potentials on the left side. Nerve-conduction studies revealed absent or barely detectable responses in the bilateral sural nerves, left superficial peroneal nerve, left median nerve, left ulnar nerve, and right radial nerve. Results of motor nerve-conduction studies were normal, as were results of a modified barium-swallow evaluation. A previous workup at another hospital for chronic diarrhea had reportedly been normal, with no evidence of malabsorption. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head (Figure 2), performed without the administration of intravenous contrast material, revealed mild diffuse parenchymal volume loss and prominent cerebellar volume loss, most notably involving the vermis and superior cerebellar hemispheres. There was mild flattening of the superior margin of the midbrain, and the ratio of midbrain to ventral pons was mildly reduced at 0.51 (reference range, >0.52).1The anteroposterior diameter of the midbrain was 8.90 mm (reference range, >9.35).1There was no abnormal signal in the pons, and the middle cerebellar peduncles were normal. There was a chronic lacunar infarct of the right thalamus. MRI of the Head.An axial T2-weighted image (Panel A) and an axial fluid-attenuated inversion recovery image (Panel B) obtained at the level of the middle cerebellar peduncles show moderate cerebellar volume loss without focal signal abnormality. A sagittal T1-weighted image (Panel C) shows moderate volume loss in the superior vermis, mild flattening of the superior margin of the midbrain, and a ratio of midbrain to ventral pons of 0.51. A parasagittal T1-weighted image (Panel D) shows moderate volume loss in the cerebellar hemispheres, predominantly the superior aspects. Additional history was obtained, and a diagnosis was made.
true_dx: Cerebellar ataxia, neuropathy, and vestibular areflexia syndrome due to a biallelic expansion inRFC1.

sentences.s: Okay, so I'm trying to figure out the diagnosis for this 69-year-old man with progressively worsening ataxia.
Let me go through the case step by step.
First, the patient developed gait abnormalities and coordination issues 9 years ago.
He has trouble walking straight, bumping into walls, and driving because he can't read signs.
His speech is also affected, and he can't sing anymore.
These symptoms point towards a cerebellar disorder since the cerebellum is responsible for motor coordination and speech.
Looking at his family history, several relatives have balance or gait issues.
His sister has a shuffling gait, and her daughter has Turner's syndrome with a balance problem.
A brother's grandson has celiac disease and a gait disturbance.
This suggests a possible inherited disorder, maybe something autosomal dominant or recessive.
His physical exam shows moderate dysarthria, wide-based gait with staggering, and inability to stand tandem.
Neurological findings include decreased vibration and joint position sense, especially in the legs.
His reflexes are mostly normal except for absent ankle jerks.
The MRI shows cerebellar volume loss, particularly the vermis and superior hemispheres, which is consistent with a cerebellar atrophy.
The lab tests are negative for common causes like vitamin deficiencies, thyroid issues, and autoimmune diseases.
There's no evidence of malabsorption or celiac-related antibodies, which might have been a consideration given the family history of celiac disease.
However, the genetic testing for spinocerebellar ataxias (SCA1-8) was negative, so it's not one of the common SCAs.
The key here is the family history and the cerebellar atrophy.
Since the patient's symptoms are slowly progressive and involve the cerebellum, and there's a family pattern, it points towards an inherited ataxia.
The absence of SCA mutations suggests it might be a less common type or another inherited condition.
Another possibility is Friedreich's ataxia, but that typically presents earlier and has other features like cardiomyopathy and diabetes, which aren't mentioned here.
Also, Friedreich's usually has a recessive pattern, and the family history doesn't strongly support that.
Given the MRI findings and the slowly progressive nature, it's more likely a cerebellar degeneration.
The family history of similar issues in multiple generations points towards an autosomal dominant condition.
Since the genetic tests for SCAs were negative, it might be a different type or a condition not yet tested, like autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxia type 3 (ADCA3) or another variant.
The patient's symptoms, especially the dysarthria and gait ataxia, along with the MRI showing cerebellar atrophy, make me think of a cerebellar degenerative process.
The family history supports an inherited cause, so the diagnosis is likely an inherited cerebellar ataxia, possibly autosomal dominant.
The patient presents with a slowly progressive cerebellar ataxia, gait disturbance, and dysarthria over 9 years.
Family history reveals multiple relatives with similar symptoms, suggesting an inherited cause.
MRI shows cerebellar volume loss, particularly in the vermis and hemispheres, consistent with cerebellar atrophy.
Lab tests rule out common metabolic and autoimmune causes.

Given the negative genetic testing for known SCAs and the autosomal dominant family pattern, the diagnosis is likely an inherited cerebellar ataxia, possibly autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxia type 3 (ADCA3) or another inherited variant.
<answer>
Autosomal Dominant Cerebellar Ataxia
</answer>

prompt: A 54-year-old man was evaluated by the neuropsychology service of this hospital because of irritability, confusion, and odd behaviors. The patient had been in his usual state of health until 9 months before the current evaluation, when he received a diagnosis of squamous-cell carcinoma of the tongue that had metastasized to the cervical lymph nodes. He underwent surgical dissection of the neck and resection of the tongue base on the right side, followed by adjuvant radiation therapy, which resulted in cancer remission. After treatment, neck pain and shoulder weakness developed and was attributed to postoperative neuropathy involving the right spinal accessory nerve. In the context of this illness and persistent pain, the patient sought care at the cancer center behavioral medicine clinic of this hospital and received a diagnosis of adjustment disorder with depression and anxiety. During the next 8 months, the patient was seen for psychotherapy approximately every 2 weeks. Treatment for the pain included physical therapy, occupational therapy, massage therapy, acupuncture, trigger-point injections, and the use of a scapular elevation brace. Therapy with oxycodone, methadone, gabapentin, tizanidine, and duloxetine was started. Four months before the current evaluation, a sural nerve graft was placed in the right spinal accessory nerve from the proximal, functioning portion to the distal portion, but the pain and weakness did not abate. Six weeks before the current evaluation, the patient did not respond to telephone calls for 24 hours. The police were called and found the patient unresponsive with prescription medication bottles nearby. Emergency medical services personnel arrived, and the initial evaluation, in the patient’s home, was notable for a severely decreased respiratory rate. Naloxone was administered, the trachea was intubated, and the patient was taken to a local hospital. In the emergency department, the patient was pulseless with ongoing electrocardiographic activity. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation was performed, and epinephrine was administered; after 4 minutes, spontaneous circulation was restored. The dose of methadone was decreased, and therapy with oxycodone, gabapentin, and tizanidine was stopped. During the subsequent 6 days, septic shock, aspiration pneumonia, acute kidney injury, and delirium occurred. When these problems resolved, the patient was discharged home. Five weeks before the current evaluation, the patient participated in a video follow-up evaluation at the behavioral medicine clinic. He expressed embarrassment and frustration related to his apparent accidental overdose. He described persistent depression, increased anxiety, and no other new symptoms. Two weeks before the current evaluation, the patient missed a routine video follow-up evaluation at the behavioral medicine clinic, and his family was called. For the preceding 2 weeks, they had noticed that the patient was uncharacteristically agitated, irritable, talking loudly, and verbally abusive. Odd behaviors were reported. The patient had gotten lost while driving to a friend’s house that he visited frequently, had been pulled over by police for driving erratically (with normal results on a breathalyzer test), and on another occasion, had been found walking along the highway under an overpass. He called family members repeatedly in the middle of the night, and he would not answer when the calls were returned. When the family requested a police wellness check of the patient, the patient retaliated by requesting a police wellness check of the family members. After this incident, the family was advised to take the patient to a local hospital for admission. At the local hospital, the patient reported no symptoms and noted that he had stopped taking methadone because he was concerned about a medication overdose. The Montreal Cognitive Assessment score was 19, indicating cognitive impairment; scores range from 0 to 30, with higher scores indicating better cognitive function.1Computed tomography (CT) of the head, performed without the administration of intravenous contrast material, revealed a nonspecific hypodensity in the centrum semiovale on the left side. The patient was told he had mild dementia. Visiting nurse services were arranged, and the patient was discharged home. One week before the current evaluation, the patient’s family reported that he had increased confusion and odd behaviors. He was unable to recall details of conversations that had happened minutes before. He could not operate the telephone or remote control and had emptied the trash can into the toilet. He had asked for his clothes to be cut off because he felt uncomfortable. Family members had been staying with the patient every night since his recent discharge because they were concerned about his safety. A neuropsychological evaluation was requested. The evaluation was conducted by the cancer center neuropsychology service of this hospital with the use of videoconferencing technology to reduce the risk of exposure to coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19). The patient acknowledged only minimal cognitive changes and was dismissive of the family’s concerns. A review of systems was notable for fatigue, moderate depression, mild anxiety, and difficulty sleeping and keeping track of time. Additional history obtained from the patient’s family included insomnia, lumbar disk herniation, olecranon bursitis, and an inguinal hernia that had led to surgical repair in early adulthood. He had had multiple concussions as a teenager, as well as a brief loss of consciousness during a motor vehicle collision 3 years earlier. After the collision, fatigue, headaches, difficulty concentrating, and impaired memory occurred; during the subsequent 2 years, occupational therapy was provided, and the symptoms gradually resolved. Medications at the time of evaluation included ibuprofen, acetaminophen, duloxetine, trazodone, melatonin, polyethylene glycol, and multivitamins. There were no known drug allergies. The patient lived alone in a suburban area of New England with family members nearby. He had completed a master’s degree and had had a successful career; he had taken a leave of absence from work 9 months earlier in anticipation of cancer treatment. After cancer treatment, he had been unable to return to work because of pain. He was athletic, walked 3 miles daily, and enjoyed golfing. He rarely drank alcohol and had never smoked tobacco or used illicit drugs. His family history included breast cancer and dementia in his mother, hearing loss and hypertension in his father, metastatic cancer with an unknown primary source in his paternal grandfather, glaucoma and alcohol use disorder in his maternal grandmother, and a brain tumor in a more distant relative. On video neuropsychological examination, the patient was in no distress and was adequately groomed, with normal-appearing hygiene. His affect was irritable, and the fact that he reported no symptoms suggested limited insight. His spontaneous speech was fluent and well articulated. His thoughts were tangential, and he was frequently forgetful and easily distracted; his information processing speed was slow. A formal neuropsychological assessment revealed impaired executive functioning, marked by disinhibition and poor working memory, as well as deficits in recent memory, verbal fluency, and information processing speed. A diagnostic test was performed.

sentences.s: Okay, so I'm trying to figure out the most likely diagnosis for this 54-year-old man based on the case presentation.
Let me go through the information step by step.
First, the patient had a history of squamous-cell carcinoma of the tongue that metastasized to the cervical lymph nodes.
He underwent surgery and radiation, which led to remission.
After that, he developed neck pain and shoulder weakness, which was attributed to postoperative neuropathy involving the right spinal accessory nerve.
He was treated with various therapies, including pain medications like oxycodone, methadone, gabapentin, tizanidine, and duloxetine, as well as other physical and occupational therapies.
Four months before evaluation, he had a sural nerve graft, but his pain and weakness didn't improve.
Six weeks prior, he had an overdose, which led to hospitalization and subsequent issues like septic shock, aspiration pneumonia, and delirium.
After that, he was discharged home but continued to have cognitive issues, as evidenced by a Montreal Cognitive Assessment score of 19, which is below the normal threshold (typically 26 or above).
His family noticed increased confusion, odd behaviors, and memory problems, which worsened over time.
During the neuropsychological evaluation, he showed deficits in executive functioning, memory, verbal fluency, and processing speed.
His behavior included irritability, confusion, and odd actions like getting lost and talking loudly.
His family history includes dementia in his mother and a brain tumor in a distant relative.
Considering all this, possible differential diagnoses include:
**Dementia**: His cognitive impairment, memory issues, and behavior changes align with this.
The MCA score supports mild cognitive impairment or early dementia.
**Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE)**: He had multiple concussions as a teenager and a loss of consciousness in a car accident, which could contribute to CTE.
However, CTE is typically associated with a history of repetitive head trauma, often seen in athletes, and may present with more behavioral changes and mood issues.
**Medication-Induced Cognitive Impairment**: He was on several medications, including methadone, which can cause cognitive side effects.
However, his symptoms persisted after reducing medications, so this might not be the primary cause.
**Post-Treatment Cognitive Dysfunction**: Sometimes, cancer treatments like radiation can cause cognitive issues.
He received radiation after surgery, which might have contributed to his cognitive decline.
**Neurotoxicity from Pain Medications**: Long-term use of opioids and other pain medications can lead to cognitive impairment.
However, his symptoms seem more persistent and severe, suggesting something more chronic.
**Vascular Cognitive Impairment**: His family history includes hypertension, which is a risk factor for vascular dementia.
However, there's no specific indication of vascular events like strokes in his history.
**Primary Dementias (e.g., Alzheimer’s Disease)**: Alzheimer’s typically presents with gradual cognitive decline, memory loss, and can have a family history.
His score on the MCA is consistent with mild Alzheimer’s, but he didn't mention significant memory issues until later, and his behavior changes were more pronounced.

Given his history of cancer, radiation, and the persistent cognitive and behavioral changes, I'm leaning towards **cognitive impairment secondary to cancer treatment (chemobrain or radiation-induced cognitive dysfunction)**.
However, the presence of a low MCA score and the gradual onset of symptoms also points towards possible early dementia.
The family history of dementia adds to this consideration.
Another angle is the possibility of **neurotoxic effects from prolonged opioid use**, but since his symptoms continued after reducing medications, this might not be the main issue.
Alternatively, **chronic traumatic encephalopathy** could be a possibility given his history of concussions, but without more evidence of repetitive trauma, it's less likely.
Considering all factors, the most likely diagnosis is **mild cognitive impairment or early dementia**, possibly related to his cancer treatment or underlying neurodegenerative process.
However, given the neuropsychological findings and the gradual onset, **dementia** seems more fitting, particularly if it's secondary to another condition like Alzheimer’s or vascular issues.

prompt: An 81-year-old man was admitted to this hospital with fever, cough, and shortness of breath during the pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19), the disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). On the morning of admission, he noted an abrupt onset of shortness of breath at rest and dyspnea on exertion. There was also substernal chest pain on the left side that worsened with deep breaths and when he lay down. The patient’s son called emergency medical services, and the patient was brought to the emergency department of this hospital for further evaluation. On arrival at the emergency department, the patient described ongoing chest pain and shortness of breath. The son reported that the patient had fallen at home 2 days before admission, but the patient did not remember falling and the son was not able to provide details about the nature or circumstances of the fall. During a previous evaluation for cough, he was reportedly told that he had a lung disease that had “caused the lung tissue to harden.” Before the onset of his most recent symptoms, he had walked outside on a daily basis without limitation from shortness of breath. He took an unknown medication for hypertension. The patient did not smoke tobacco, use illicit drugs, or drink alcohol. He lived in an apartment with his wife. On examination, the temperature was 37.9°C, the blood pressure 157/95 mm Hg, the pulse 112 beats per minute, the respiratory rate 30 breaths per minute, and the oxygen saturation 91% while the patient was breathing ambient air. The body-mass index (the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters) was 22.8. Retractions were noted in the supraclavicular areas. sentences.s: Okay, so I'm trying to figure out the diagnosis for this 81-year-old man who was admitted with fever, cough, and shortness of breath during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Let me go through the case step by step.
First, the patient developed fever and cough three days before admission, and then suddenly had shortness of breath and chest pain two days later.
His son mentioned he fell two days before, but he doesn't remember it, and there's no info on the fall's details.
He has a history of hypertension and was told he had a lung disease causing hardening of the lung tissue.
That makes me think of something like pulmonary fibrosis, maybe idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) since it causes lung tissue scarring.
Looking at the vital signs: temp is 37.9°C, BP 157/95, pulse 112, RR 30, oxygen 91%.
On supplemental oxygen, RR went down to 28 and O2 to 96%.
So he's tachypneic and a bit hypoxic.
BMI is 22.8, which is low-normal, so not obese.
Physical exam shows retractions, inspiratory crackles at the lung bases.
Heart sounds regular, tachycardic, no murmur.
No chest wall tenderness, no leg edema.
So no signs of heart failure or pleuritis.
Lab results: WBC is 11,920, which is elevated.
Neutrophils are 10,100, so neutrophilic leukocytosis.
Lymphocytes are low at 850.
Monocytes 600, eosinophils 40, and immature granulocytes 280.
So this suggests a bacterial or viral infection.
Ferritin is high at 1760, which is indicative of inflammation or infection.
CRP is 185, which is way above normal, so definitely an inflammatory response.
Other labs: LDH is 1340, which is elevated.
LDH is often elevated in interstitial lung diseases or in infection.
ALT and AST are elevated too, 70 and 128 respectively, which could be due to liver stress from infection or maybe something else.
Alkaline phosphatase is 128, also elevated, but not super high.
Bilirubin is 1.7, which is direct 0.5, so maybe some hepatocellular injury or cholestasis.
Chest X-ray shows bilateral patchy airspace opacities more on the left, mostly peripheral with sparing of perihilar regions.
That's the "reverse batwing" sign, which is classic for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
Also, there's mild bronchiectasis and reticular opacities, which could be old fibrosis.
ECG shows sinus tachycardia, nothing else.
They started him on azithromycin and ceftriaxone, which are broad-spectrum antibiotics, but given the pandemic, COVID-19 was a big consideration.
On the medical floor, his condition worsened: RR 40, O2 86% on 4L, then 5L and morphine.
Severe pleuritic chest pain.
Now, putting it all together.
He has a history of pulmonary disease (probably IPF), and now presents with ARDS-like symptoms.
The CXR shows reverse batwing, which is ARDS.
His labs show high CRP, LDH, elevated WBCs, which are consistent with infection or inflammation.
The fact that he's on day 3 of symptoms with a rapid progression makes me think of a viral cause, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic.
He tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 RNA, which would explain the ARDS.
His underlying IPF could have made him more susceptible to severe COVID-19.
The pleuritic chest pain could be due to pulmonary inflammation or maybe a small pulmonary embolism, but the D-dimer was >10,000, which is elevated, suggesting possible PE.
However, the main issue seems to be his respiratory failure.
So, the most likely diagnosis is COVID-19 causing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) in the context of his pre-existing interstitial lung disease.

pred_dx: Spontaneous brachial artery hematoma due to atherosclerotic medial calcification

sentences.s: Okay, so I'm trying to figure out the diagnosis for this 82-year-old woman who presented with pain, swelling, and ecchymosis in her left arm.
Let me go through the case step by step.
First, the patient's history: She suddenly developed swelling and discoloration in her left arm above the elbow without any trauma.
Over the next few days, it spread to the elbow, forearm, wrist, and digits.
She had some lab work and imaging done, including CT scans.
Looking at the lab results, her white blood cell count was elevated, but not extremely high.
Her platelet count was normal, and her coagulation studies showed a slightly elevated d-dimer and fibrinogen.
Her creatine kinase was elevated, which might suggest muscle injury or a hematoma.
The imaging findings were interesting.
The CT showed a disproportionate enlargement of the brachioradialis muscle, suggesting an intramuscular hematoma.
There was also hyperdense stranding in the subcutaneous fat, consistent with hemorrhage.
The CT angiography revealed heavy atherosclerotic plaque in the left subclavian artery with about 70-80% stenosis.
The arteries in the arm were otherwise patent, and there were no signs of active hemorrhage or aneurysms.
Considering her age and medical history, she has hypertension, dyslipidemia, peripheral vascular disease, and chronic kidney disease.
These are all risk factors for atherosclerosis.
The stenosis in the left subclavian artery could lead to reduced blood flow to the arm, but in this case, the imaging didn't show any signs of acute ischemia or thrombus formation.

The initial presentation with swelling and discoloration without trauma makes me think of compartment syndrome, but the absence of ischemic changes on imaging and the presence of a hematoma suggest something else.
Another possibility is a spontaneous hematoma, which can occur in the setting of atherosclerosis or vessel wall weakening.

Given the heavy atherosclerotic plaque and the presence of a hematoma, the most likely diagnosis is atherosclerotic medial calcification leading to spontaneous rupture of a vessel, causing an intramuscular hematoma.
This is sometimes referred to as a spontaneous brachial artery hematoma, which can occur when there's significant atherosclerosis causing weakening of the arterial wall.
The patient's age and vascular risk factors support this.

So, putting it all together, the diagnosis is likely a spontaneous hematoma due to atherosclerotic changes in the left subclavian artery leading to vessel wall weakening and rupture, resulting in an intramuscular hematoma in the left arm.

The patient's presentation, lab results, and imaging findings, combined with her significant atherosclerotic risk factors, point to a spontaneous hematoma caused by atherosclerotic medial calcification leading to vessel wall weakening and rupture.

The patient was discharged from the emergency department of the other hospital on the same day, with a referral to the rheumatology clinic of that hospital and instructions to start treatment with prednisone. One day after discharge, one of the four culture bottles grew gram-positive bacilli, and the patient was admitted to the other hospital for investigation. After an evaluation, the positive culture was presumed to be contaminated. Additional blood specimens were obtained for culture, and the patient was discharged home on the second hospital day. The fever and chills resolved, and the abdominal pain abated initially but then gradually worsened. Eight days after discharge and 3 days before the current admission, the patient returned to the emergency department of the other hospital. On examination, the temperature was 36.8°C, the pulse 50 beats per minute, and the blood pressure 146/78 mm Hg. Physical examination was notable for diffuse abdominal tenderness, which was worse with deep palpation in all four quadrants. Hep C can cause vasculitis, including abdominal aortic involvement.
The aortic changes could be due to aneurysms from repeated inflammation or infection.
Another possibility is Takayasu arteritis, a form of giant cell arteritis affecting the aorta, but that's more common in younger women and can present with aortic dilation.
However, she has a history of IV drug use, which complicates things because infections like endocarditis or mycotic aneurysms are possibilities, but the cultures didn't grow anything conclusive.
She was on prednisone, which can cause steroid-induced atherosclerosis, but that usually doesn't cause such rapid dilation.
The fact that her aorta continued to enlarge despite treatment makes me think it's more of an ongoing inflammatory or infectious process.
Given her Hep C positivity and the aortic changes, I'm leaning towards Hepatitis C-related aortitis or possibly polyarteritis nodosa, which can involve the aorta.
Polyarteritis nodosa is a systemic vasculitis that can affect medium-sized arteries, including the aorta, leading to aneurysms.
Alternatively, considering her IV drug use, a mycotic aneurysm is a possibility, but the lack of positive cultures makes that less likely.
Also, the progression of the aortic dilation over time suggests a chronic process rather than an acute infection.
Another angle is the possibility of rheumatoid arthritis, given her family history, but her lab tests don't show positive rheumatoid factor or CCP antibodies.
Her ESR and CRP are high, but that's consistent with inflammation, not necessarily RA.
The patient's history of prednisone use could also contribute to atherosclerosis, but again, the rapid progression points more towards an active inflammatory or infectious cause.
Putting it all together, the most likely diagnosis is Hepatitis C-related aortitis or possibly polyarteritis nodosa.
Both can cause aortic dilation and are associated with systemic vasculitis.
Given her Hep C positivity and the imaging findings, I think Hepatitis C-related aortitis is the more specific diagnosis here.

The patient's presentation, including abdominal pain, aortic dilatation, and systemic inflammation, along with her history of IV drug use and positive Hepatitis C antibody, points towards Hepatitis C-related aortitis as the most likely diagnosis.
This condition can cause systemic vasculitis leading to aortic dilation and aneurysms.

Additional laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Chest radiography revealed mild pulmonary interstitial edema. Ultrasonography of the kidneys and urinary tract revealed simple cysts in the left kidney, with no evidence of hydronephrosis or nephrolithiasis. Intravenous fluids were administered, and a diagnosis was made.
true_dx: Lactic acidosis due to toxic effects from metformin use.
pred_dx: Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) secondary to Heart Failure with Acute Tubular Necrosis and Lactic Acidosis

sentences.s: Okay, so I'm trying to figure out the diagnosis for this 76-year-old woman.
Let's go through the case step by step.
First, her medical history includes heart failure, type 2 diabetes, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, and obstructive sleep apnea.
She's been in a skilled nursing facility after a humeral fracture.
Her current symptoms are nausea, diarrhea, and acute kidney failure.
Looking at her lab results, her creatinine is 7.66 mg/dL, which is way above the normal range of 0.60-1.50.
That definitely points to acute kidney injury (AKI).
Her lactic acid is elevated at 7.4 mmol/L, which is concerning because normal is up to 2.0.
High lactate can indicate tissue hypoperfusion or lactic acidosis.
She had a recent hospitalization 3 months ago for respiratory failure and pneumonia, treated with ceftriaxone and doxycycline.
Then, 9 weeks ago, she was discharged with torsemide and spironolactone.
Four weeks before admission, she fell, fractured her humerus, and was sent to a nursing facility.
Two weeks prior, she developed leg edema, which resolved with metolazone addition.
At admission, she's on several medications, including diuretics (metolazone, spironolactone, torsemide), which she hasn't taken for over 24 hours.
Her last dose was more than a day ago, so it's less likely that acute diuretic effects are causing her AKI.
She's not on any new medications recently, and no known allergies.
Her symptoms started in the nursing facility, where she might have been exposed to infections or had issues with her medications.
Looking at her lab work, besides the elevated creatinine and lactic acid, her anion gap is 29, which is high.
The anion gap is calculated as (Na + Cl) - (K + HCO3).
Her sodium is 136, chloride 96, potassium 4.4, and bicarbonate 20.
Wait, that doesn't make sense.
Maybe I'm miscalculating.
Alternatively, the anion gap is given as 29, which is elevated.
This suggests an anion gap metabolic acidosis.
She also has a high white cell count, with neutrophils elevated, which might indicate infection.
However, her recent treatment with antibiotics could contribute to that.
Her troponin is elevated at 2869 ng/L, which is significantly above normal (normal up to 9 ng/L).
This suggests possible myocardial injury, which could be related to her heart failure decompensating.
Her BNP is elevated at 5935 pg/mL, which is consistent with heart failure.
Her chest X-ray shows pulmonary interstitial edema, supporting heart failure as a cause of her symptoms.
Now, considering the possible causes of AKI in this patient.
She has a history of heart failure, which can lead to reduced cardiac output and renal hypoperfusion (prerenal AKI).
Her elevated lactate and anion gap suggest possible lactic acidosis, which can occur in shock or severe tissue hypoperfusion.
The high troponin and BNP support ongoing heart failure, which could be causing decreased renal perfusion.
Another possibility is acute tubular necrosis (ATN), which is common in prerenal AKI that progresses.
ATN can result from prolonged hypoperfusion leading to tubular damage.
Her elevated creatinine and lactic acid could fit this picture.
She doesn't have signs of obstruction (urinalysis is normal, no flank pain), so postrenal causes are less likely.
Her labs don't show a clear infection pattern beyond the elevated WBC, which could be due to her heart failure or other factors.
Given her history of heart failure, the most likely diagnosis is acute kidney injury secondary to heart failure, specifically prerenal azotemia progressing to acute tubular necrosis.
The elevated lactate and anion gap support the idea of tissue hypoperfusion leading to lactic acidosis.
So, putting it all together, the diagnosis is likely acute kidney injury (AKI) secondary to heart failure, possibly progressing to acute tubular necrosis, complicated by lactic acidosis.

They may therefore not be appropriate for all patients. Nausea and fatigue persisted. Three months before admission, the patient was again evaluated by her primary care provider at the other hospital. The weight was 84.4 kg; the remainder of the examination was unchanged. Blood levels of electrolytes and glucose were normal, as were the results of kidney-function tests; other laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis, performed after the administration of intravenous contrast material, revealed cholelithiasis and splenomegaly, with the spleen measuring 17 cm in the craniocaudal dimension (normal value, ≤12 cm). Two and a half months before admission, the patient was evaluated in a hematology clinic affiliated with the other hospital. She reported persistent nausea and fatigue, poor appetite with reduced oral intake, and 2 weeks of dyspnea on exertion. There was no orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. The weight was 83.2 kg, and the spleen tip was palpable four fingerbreadths below the costal margin; the remainder of the physical examination was normal. A bone marrow biopsy was performed, and examination of the bone marrow specimen revealed mildly hypercellular marrow with maturing trilineage hematopoiesis and mild dyserythropoiesis. Treatment with prednisone and folic acid was begun. Ocrelizumab infusions for multiple sclerosis were stopped. Nausea and fatigue persisted, and fevers and sweats developed. After 3 weeks of treatment with prednisone, the anemia had not abated and the patient had temperatures as high as 39.0°C. Testing for influenza A and B viruses was negative. Two units of packed red cells were transfused. The course of prednisone was tapered off over the next 18 days, and the patient was referred to a hematologist affiliated with this hospital. In the hematology clinic, the patient reported that the fevers had resolved but the fatigue, weakness, and poor appetite had worsened. She felt too fatigued to walk, and she had recently had a fall without loss of consciousness. The weight was 82.4 kg; splenomegaly was present, and the remainder of the examination was unchanged. The patient was admitted to this hospital for further evaluation and treatment. In addition to relapsing–remitting multiple sclerosis, there was a history of trigeminal neuralgia, restless legs syndrome, vasovagal syncope when blood samples were obtained, and an elevated alkaline phosphatase level for 1 year without a clear cause. Medications included oxcarbazepine, gabapentin, ropinirole, folic acid, and cholecalciferol. There were no known drug allergies. The patient had quit smoking 20 years earlier and did not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. She lived in a suburban area of New England with her adult son and pet cat and dog. Her backyard adjoined a large wooded area where deer were often seen. She worked in health care administration. Her family history included diabetes in her mother, lung cancer in her father, and multiple sclerosis in her sister. On examination, the patient appeared pale but not unwell. The temperature was 38.3°C, the blood pressure 90/54 mm Hg, the heart rate 93 beats per minute, the respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, and the oxygen saturation 93% while she was breathing ambient air. The weight was 79.8 kg and the body-mass index (the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters) 32.2. The conjunctivae were pale. The heart rate was regular, with normal first and second heart sounds (S1and S2) and a soft systolic murmur. There was edema in the legs. The remainder of the examination was normal. Blood levels of homocysteine, methylmalonic acid, arsenic, cadmium, lead, and mercury were normal, as were the results of serum protein electrophoresis and coagulation tests; other laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Blood cultures were obtained. Two units of packed red cells were transfused, and one dose of intravenous furosemide was administered. Intravenous methylprednisolone was administered daily for 3 days, and the patient reported a decrease in weakness and fatigue. On hospital day 4, CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis (Figure 1A) revealed splenomegaly, with the spleen measuring 19 cm in the craniocaudal dimension. Concurrent positron-emission tomography with injection of18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (Figure 1B) revealed intense uptake in the spleen and diffuse uptake in the bone marrow throughout the axial and appendicular skeleton. Imaging Studies.A CT image of the abdomen (Panel A), obtained after the administration of intravenous contrast material, shows moderate splenomegaly, with the spleen (S) measuring 19 cm in the craniocaudal dimension and with its inferior margin extending beyond the inferior margin of the liver (L). There are also gallstones (arrow) in the gallbladder. A maximum-intensity-projection positron-emission tomographic image with injection of18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) (Panel B) shows increased FDG uptake in the spleen, as compared with the liver, and diffuse FDG uptake in the bone marrow throughout the axial and appendicular skeleton. On hospital day 5, the patient reported a recurrence of severe fatigue and generalized weakness. The temperature was 39.0°C and the heart rate 130 beats per minute. The results of physical examination were otherwise unchanged. Laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. A diagnostic test result was received.

sentences.s: Okay, so I'm trying to figure out the diagnosis for this 64-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis who presented with fever and pancytopenia.
Let me go through the case step by step.
First, her medical history includes multiple sclerosis, which is important because she was on ocrelizumab, a medication that can affect the immune system.
She stopped it a few months before admission, which might be relevant.
Her symptoms started 7 months prior with nausea and fatigue, which worsened over time.
She had two episodes of vasovagal syncope, which led to an evaluation where anemia was noted.
Her lab work initially showed normal electrolytes, glucose, and other parameters, but her anemia persisted.
She was given iron supplementation, but that didn't help.
Looking at her lab results, her hemoglobin and hematocrit were low, and she had a high mean corpuscular volume (MCV), which suggests a macrocytic anemia.
Her reticulocyte count was elevated, indicating some degree of bone marrow response.
However, her platelet count was low, and her white blood cell count was also low, with lymphopenia.
This pancytopenia is a key finding.
The bone marrow biopsy showed mildly hypercellular marrow with maturing trilineage hematopoiesis and mild dyserythropoiesis.
That doesn't point to a specific diagnosis yet but suggests a problem in the bone marrow.
Her ferritin was elevated (1248 μg/L), which is a marker of inflammation or chronic disease, not iron deficiency.
Her LDH was elevated, which can be seen in hemolytic conditions or other inflammatory processes.
The Coombs' tests were negative, so it's not immune-mediated hemolytic anemia.
Imaging showed splenomegaly (17 cm) and on further imaging, the spleen was even larger (19 cm).
The PET scan showed increased FDG uptake in the spleen and bone marrow, which is suggestive of a hypermetabolic process, possibly malignancy or an infiltrative process.
She had a fever of up to 39°C, which along with pancytopenia, is concerning for an infection or a systemic process like leukemia or lymphoma.
However, her blood cultures were negative, which makes infection less likely, especially if there's no other source.
The elevated alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin could indicate liver involvement, but her liver function tests didn't show a clear pattern of hepatitis or cholestasis.
The triglycerides were elevated, but that's more likely related to her weight and possibly metabolic syndrome.
Considering all this, the key points are pancytopenia, splenomegaly, bone marrow involvement, and hypermetabolic imaging.
These findings are consistent with a hematologic malignancy.
The most likely diagnosis here is acute myeloid leukemia (AML), given the bone marrow findings and the imaging.
However, another possibility is myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), but the presence of fever and rapid progression leans more towards AML.
She responded transiently to steroids, which can happen in some leukemias, but the underlying disease would still progress.
The elevated ferritin supports an inflammatory or chronic process, which is seen in AML.
So, putting it all together, the most likely diagnosis is acute myeloid leukemia.
<answer>
Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)
</answer>

prompt: A newborn girl was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit of this hospital after a planned delivery by cesarean section because of a neck mass. During pregnancy, the patient’s mother was 41 years old (gravida 3, para 1) and received prenatal care at another hospital. At 7 weeks of gestation, vaginal bleeding occurred because of a subchorionic hematoma. At 10 weeks of gestation, the mother’s blood thyrotropin level was 0.01 μU per milliliter (reference range, 0.40 to 5.00); levels of free thyroxine (free T4) and total triiodothyronine (total T3) were not obtained. At 19 weeks of gestation, the thyrotropin level was 0.44 μU per milliliter and an ultrasonographic survey of the fetal anatomy was normal. During the third trimester, gestational diabetes was diagnosed; glycemic control was maintained with dietary changes. Four weeks before delivery, at 34 weeks 6 days of gestation, a routine transvaginal ultrasonographic survey of fetal growth revealed a new mass on the right side of the fetus’s neck that measured 2.6 cm by 3.4 cm by 3.0 cm. The mother was referred to the obstetrics clinic of this hospital for further evaluation and treatment. At 35 weeks 6 days of gestation, obstetrical ultrasonography performed at this hospital (Figure 1A) confirmed the presence of a 4.6-cm mass on the right side of the neck. The mass was hyperechoic and well circumscribed and had internal vascularity; the remainder of the survey of fetal anatomy was normal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the fetus, performed without the intravenous administration of contrast material (Figure 1B, 1C, and 1D), revealed displacement of the trachea without compression. Prenatal Imaging Studies.Ultrasonography and MRI of the fetus were performed at 35 weeks 6 days of gestation. An ultrasound image (Panel A) shows a 4.6-cm spherical mass on the right side of the neck. T2-weighted MRIs (Panels B, C, and D) show a single fetus in the vertex position (Panel B) with a spherical mass (Panels B and C, arrows; Panel D, asterisk) on the right side of the neck and displacement of the trachea (Panel D, arrow). For multiple weeks, the fetal biophysical profile score was 8 out of 8, indicating normal breathing motion, movement, tone, and amniotic fluid volume. The mother met with providers from Maternal–Fetal Medicine, Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Otolaryngology, and Neonatology to discuss the plan for delivery and neonatal airway management at birth, including the possibility of an ex utero intrapartum treatment (EXIT) procedure. The mother initially had a preference for a vaginal delivery, given her history of a successful vaginal delivery with a previous pregnancy. However, after conversations with Maternal–Fetal Medicine providers, the decision was made to proceed with a scheduled cesarean section at 39 weeks of gestation to minimize the risks of labor dystocia and asynclitism due to fetal neck position and any associated birth trauma, as well as to allow for controlled timing of the delivery with multidisciplinary team members present. The mother had a history of anxiety, post-traumatic stress disorder, and known mutations in both copies of the gene encoding methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR). Eleven years earlier, her first pregnancy had ended at full term with a vaginal delivery. Three years earlier, her second pregnancy had ended at 13 weeks of gestation with elective termination because of the diagnosis of pentalogy of Cantrell (a syndrome of midline abdominal and chest wall defects, including ectopia cordis and omphalocele). During her current pregnancy, she had taken prenatal vitamins, cholecalciferol, and pyridoxine, as well as lorazepam as needed for anxiety. Prenatal screening tests were negative for gonorrhea, chlamydia, syphilis, human immunodeficiency virus, and hepatitis B; equivocal for immunity to rubella; and positive for group B streptococcal colonization. The patient (baby) had a healthy father and sister. Her family history included hypothyroidism in her maternal grandmother, sleep apnea in her paternal grandfather, and diabetes in her paternal grandmother. In addition, her maternal aunt had thyrotoxicosis, a paternal uncle had diabetes, and another paternal uncle had blindness, deafness, and cognitive developmental delay. At 39 weeks of gestation, the baby was delivered by cesarean section. The birth weight was 3060 g (35th percentile), the length 48 cm (26th percentile), and the head circumference 34.5 cm (60th percentile). She had a spontaneous cry, decreased tone, and spontaneous respirations. There was a large firm mass on the right side of the neck. The 1-minute Apgar score was 6. At 3 minutes of life, increased work of breathing developed; treatment with continuous positive airway pressure of 5 cm of water was administered. At 5 minutes of life, the Apgar score was 7 but the increased work of breathing worsened, with nasal flaring, grunting, and subcostal retractions; the fraction of inspired oxygen (Fio2) was increased to 100%. At 10 minutes of life, the Apgar score was 8. Direct laryngoscopy revealed deviation of the trachea, larynx, subglottis, and right piriform sinus. Tracheal intubation was performed with rigid bronchoscopy; because of clinically significant airway obstruction, tracheostomy was performed. At 8 hours of life, the blood hemoglobin level was 10.0 g per deciliter (reference range for neonates, 13.5 to 19.5), the thyrotropin level 3.82 μU per milliliter, the alpha-fetoprotein level 107,048.0 ng per milliliter (reference range, <7.9), and the beta human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level 7.3 IU per milliliter (reference range, <50.0). Other laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. sentences.s: Okay, so I'm trying to figure out the diagnosis for this newborn girl based on the case presentation.
Let me go through the information step by step.
First, the mother is 41 years old, which is on the higher side but not extremely rare.
She's gravida 3, para 1, so she's had three pregnancies and one child.
She had a history of a previous pregnancy that ended at full term with a vaginal delivery, and another that ended at 13 weeks with an elective termination due to pentalogy of Cantrell.
That's a syndrome involving midline abdominal and chest wall defects, including ectopia cordis and omphalocele.
So, there's a family history of some congenital issues, but not directly related to the current problem.
During this pregnancy, she had vaginal bleeding at 7 weeks due to a subchorionic hematoma.
Then, at 10 weeks, her thyrotropin level was 0.01 μU/mL, which is low.
The reference range is 0.40-5.00, so this suggests hypothyroidism.
However, they didn't check free T4 and total T3 at that time.
At 19 weeks, her TSH was 0.44 μU/mL, still low but within the lower end of normal.
They did an anatomy scan which was normal.
In the third trimester, she was diagnosed with gestational diabetes, managed with diet.
Four weeks before delivery, at 34 weeks, a routine ultrasound showed a neck mass on the right side, 2.6x3.4x3.0 cm.
Follow-up at 35 weeks showed it had grown to 4.6 cm.
The mass was hyperechoic, well-circumscribed, with internal vascularity.
MRI showed displacement of the trachea without compression.
The biophysical profile was normal, so the baby was doing well in utero.
They discussed delivery options, including an EXIT procedure, but decided on a cesarean section at 39 weeks to avoid dystocia and birth trauma.
The baby was born with a large neck mass, decreased tone, and some respiratory distress.
The Apgar scores were 6, 7, then 8.
They had to intubate and eventually did a tracheostomy due to airway obstruction.
Looking at the lab results: at 8 hours of life, her TSH was 3.82 μU/mL, which is slightly elevated.
Her alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) was 107,048 ng/mL, way above the reference of <7.9.
Beta-hCG was 7.3 IU/mL, also elevated but not as high as AFP.
The white blood cell count was 17,530, which is elevated, but within the range.
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) was 319 U/L, elevated as well.
Postnatal imaging showed the mass was hypervascular, arising from the sympathetic chain.
AFP and beta-hCG levels are significantly elevated, which makes me think of teratomas or other germ cell tumors.
The mass is in the neck, which is a common site for teratomas, especially in females.
Teratomas are germ cell tumors that can produce AFP and hCG.
The AFP level here is extremely high, which is a hallmark of teratoma.
Beta-hCG is also elevated, supporting this.
The mass's origin from the sympathetic chain on imaging also aligns with a teratoma, as these tumors can arise from primitive streak cells, which include germ cells.
Other possibilities could include a thyroglobulin-secreting tumor, but the TSH levels don't suggest thyroid issues as the primary problem.
The initial low TSH in the mother could be due to hypothyroidism, but the baby's TSH is elevated postnatally, which might be a reaction to the mass or other factors.
The family history includes hypothyroidism and other conditions, but nothing directly pointing to a genetic syndrome here.
The imaging showing the mass's vascularity and location further supports a teratoma.

So, putting it all together, the most likely diagnosis is a neck teratoma, specifically a畸胎瘤 (teratoma) in the neck, given the elevated AFP and beta-hCG levels, the imaging findings, and the clinical presentation.

prompt: A 78-year-old man was admitted to this hospital because of a rash on the forehead and frontal scalp and edema of the left eyelids. The patient had been well until 3 days before presentation, when pressurelike pain developed in the left side of the forehead and frontal scalp and the bilateral maxillary sinuses and upper jaws. He described the pain as similar to previous episodes of sinusitis. He was evaluated in the primary care clinic of another hospital, and treatment with oral clindamycin was started for a presumed diagnosis of sinusitis. Two days before presentation, the patient noted erythema and small reddish-brown skin lesions on the left side of the forehead and frontal scalp. His barber had pointed out a similar spot on the top of his scalp 2 weeks earlier. The skin lesions were not painful or itchy, and he did not seek medical evaluation. On the day of presentation, the patient awoke from sleep and noted redness and swelling of the left eyelids. The skin lesions on the left side of the forehead and frontal scalp had increased in number, and some were covered with hemorrhagic crust. There was pain with movement of the left eye and blurry vision. Over the course of several hours, the swelling of the left eyelids worsened and the patient was unable to fully open the left eye. He presented to the emergency department of this hospital for evaluation. In the emergency department, the patient reported no ocular or nasal discharge, no changes in taste or hearing, and no jaw claudication. He had not recently changed his shampoo or been in a pool or hot tub. He had a history of recurrent sinus infection, allergic rhinitis, depression, benign prostatic hyperplasia, hypogonadism, and restless legs syndrome. He had received a diagnosis of rectal cancer 15 years earlier, which had led to partial colectomy, as well as a diagnosis of testicular cancer 50 years earlier, which had led to orchiectomy and radiation therapy. His ocular history included bilateral mild ptosis; he had undergone bilateral cataract extraction with intraocular lens implantation. Medications included finasteride, tamsulosin, carbidopa–levodopa, nasal azelastine and fluticasone, and topical testosterone. Levofloxacin, cefaclor, and sulfamethoxazole–trimethoprim had caused a rash. The patient was a retired engineer and lived with his wife in a coastal community of New England. He had previously smoked a pipe but had quit 30 years earlier. He drank a quarter glass of wine daily. His family history included skin cancer in his maternal grandmother and macular degeneration in his sister. On examination, the temperature was 38.1°C, the blood pressure 122/58 mm Hg, and the heart rate 74 beats per minute. The body-mass index (the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters) was 31.9. Visual acuity without glasses was 20/40 in the right eye and 20/50 in the left eye. Results of Ishihara color testing were normal. The pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light; there was no relative afferent pupillary defect. Extraocular movements were full. There was complete ptosis of the left upper eyelid, along with erythema and edema of left upper and lower lids. There was mild ptosis of the right upper lid. There was no proptosis. The intraocular pressure was 17 mm Hg in both eyes. Slit-lamp examination revealed diffuse conjunctival injection and inferior chemosis in the left eye. The corneas were clear, and no cells were visualized in the anterior chambers. Results of dilated fundoscopic examination were normal. There was prominent erythema affecting the forehead, left side of the anterior scalp, and left eyelids. Multiple coalescing erosions covered with hemorrhagic and serous crust were seen at sites of erythema, mainly affecting the left side of the forehead and extending to the midline, the frontal scalp, and the left upper eyelid. Erosions and erythema affected the right side of the forehead, as well, but to a much lesser extent. The remainder of the physical examination was normal. Laboratory evaluation revealed a blood sodium level of 125 mmol per liter (reference range, 135 to 145). Results of kidney- and liver-function tests were normal. Tests for human immunodeficiency virus types 1 and 2 were negative. Other laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. They may therefore not be appropriate for all patients. Computed tomography (CT) of the head and face (Figure 1), performed after the administration of intravenous contrast material, revealed marked swelling affecting the soft tissue over the left orbit and frontal sinus and extending superiorly along the superficial soft tissue of the frontal scalp, predominantly on the left side. The globe, orbit, and retrobulbar soft tissue were normal. The right maxillary sinus showed nearly complete opacification with wall thickening and sclerosis, findings consistent with chronic inflammation and sinusitis. There was a defect in the medial wall of the right maxillary sinus that was consistent with previous sinus surgery. The other paranasal sinuses, including the left maxillary sinus, ethmoid sinuses, and sphenoid sinuses, were well aerated. CT of the Head and Face.Axial images obtained after the administration of intravenous contrast material and reconstructed in soft-tissue algorithm (Panels A and B) show marked edema of the left eyelids and preseptal soft tissues superficial to the left orbit (Panel A, arrows) and fluid and edema within the frontal scalp (Panel B, arrow). No postseptal inflammatory changes are present; the normal and symmetric appearance of the orbital fat is consistent with findings on a representative coronal image reconstructed in soft-tissue algorithm (Panel C). A coronal image reconstructed in bone algorithm (Panel D) at the same anatomical level as the representative image shows nearly complete opacification of the right maxillary sinus with thickening and sclerosis of the walls of the right maxillary sinus (arrow), findings consistent with chronic sinusitis. A defect in the medial wall of the right maxillary sinus (arrowhead) is consistent with previous sinus surgery. The other paranasal sinuses, including the left maxillary sinus, ethmoid sinuses, and sphenoid sinuses bordering the left orbit, are well aerated. Empirical treatment with valacyclovir, amoxicillin–clavulanate, and topical bacitracin–polymyxin B was started. The next day, the edema and erythema of the left eyelids worsened, and there was new edema and erythema of the right eyelids. The patient was unable to open his eyes. He began to have visual hallucinations, and his wife noted that he was confused. The skin lesions on the left side of the forehead were unchanged, and new round punched-out erosions with overlying hemorrhagic crust were present on the right side of the forehead (Figure 2). Empirical treatment with intravenous vancomycin, cefepime, and acyclovir was started. Clinical Photographs.Panel A shows a rash located predominantly in the left cranial nerve (V1) dermatomal distribution, mainly involving the left side of the forehead and left upper eyelid, with partial demarcation at the midline of the forehead (arrows). There is clinically significant edema of the eyelids, which is more pronounced on the left side than on the right side. Of note, the nose is spared. Panel B shows involvement of the frontal scalp (arrow). Panels C and D show multiple grouped and confluent violaceous eroded papules with hemorrhagic and serous crust with underlying erythema (arrows). Panel E shows erythema involving the entire forehead, as well as smaller erosions with hemorrhagic crust (arrow) and multiple pustules (arrowhead) involving the right side of the forehead. A diagnostic test was performed.
pred_dx: Malignant melanoma involving the trigeminal nerve

sentences.s: Okay, so I'm trying to figure out the diagnosis for this 78-year-old man.
Let's go through the case step by step.
First, the patient presented with a rash on his forehead and frontal scalp, along with edema of the left eyelids.
He initially thought it was sinusitis because of the pressure-like pain in his left forehead and maxillary sinuses.
He was treated with clindamycin, but two days later, the rash appeared.
It started on the left side and then spread, with some areas having hemorrhagic crusts.
The rash wasn't itchy or painful, but the eyelid swelling worsened, causing him to have trouble opening his left eye and some blurry vision.
Looking at his history, he has a past of recurrent sinus infections, which makes me think of sinus-related issues.
He also had rectal and testicular cancers, but I don't see a direct link there.
His medications include finasteride, tamsulosin, and topical testosterone, which can sometimes cause skin reactions, but the rash didn't start until after the clindamycin was prescribed.
The physical exam showed significant edema and erythema on the left side, with erosions and crusts.
The CT scan revealed swelling in the soft tissues around the left orbit and frontal sinus, but no orbital involvement.
The right maxillary sinus had chronic changes, which aligns with his history of sinus issues.
The lab results showed a slightly elevated C-reactive protein and a normal white cell count.
The rash didn't seem to respond well to initial treatments, which included antiviral and antibiotic therapy.
The progression to both eyes and the appearance of new lesions on the right side made me think it wasn't just a simple infection.

Considering all this, the rash's distribution along the trigeminal nerve (V1) dermatome, the lack of response to antibiotics, and the possibility of a neurological component, especially with the confusion and hallucinations, led me to think of something more serious.
Malignant tumors like melanoma or squamous cell carcinoma can spread along nerves, causing such rashes.
The patient's history of skin cancer in his family and his previous cancers might be a clue, but the presentation here is more acute.
Another possibility is a neurological infection, but the labs didn't show typical signs, and the treatment with antivirals didn't help.
The rash's progression and the involvement of both eyes made me lean towards a malignancy that's spreading along the trigeminal nerve.
This could explain the pain, rash, and later neurological symptoms like confusion.
So, putting it all together, the most likely diagnosis is melanoma involving the trigeminal nerve, possibly spreading from a primary site elsewhere.
The rash's distribution and the patient's history make this a strong possibility.
The patient presented with a rapidly progressing rash and edema, initially thought to be sinusitis.
The rash, located in the V1 dermatome, worsened despite treatment and spread to both sides.
The involvement of the trigeminal nerve, along with the lack of response to antibiotics and antivirals, suggested a more serious underlying condition.
The patient's history of skin cancer in the family and previous cancers, though not directly linked, raised suspicion of malignancy.
The most likely diagnosis is melanoma involving the trigeminal nerve.

prompt: A 39-year-old woman presented to this hospital with fever, flank pain, and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. The patient had been in her usual state of health until approximately 4 weeks before admission, when she noted tender bilateral inguinal swelling. Two days later, she began to have sharp, intermittent flank pain on the right side; she rated the pain at 5 on a scale of 0 to 10, with 10 indicating the most severe pain. During the next 3 days, she had nausea and a poor appetite. She noted foul-smelling urine but had no dysuria, urinary frequency, or hematuria. Three weeks before admission, the patient was evaluated by her primary care physician. On examination, the temperature was 36.6°C, and she appeared well. There was costovertebral and abdominal tenderness on the right side, without rebound or guarding. The external genitalia were normal. Copious thin, white vaginal discharge was present; no cervical motion tenderness was noted, and the ovaries were normal on palpation. Multiple bilateral tender inguinal lymph nodes, measuring up to 2 cm in diameter, were noted on palpation. The remainder of the physical examination was normal. On microscopic examination of the vaginal discharge, clue cells were observed, but there were no fungal elements or trichomonads. Nucleic acid amplification tests of a cervical swab forChlamydia trachomatisandNeisseria gonorrhoeaewere negative. A blood test for IgM, IgG, and IgA antibodies toC. trachomatisserovars L1 and D through K was negative. Urinalysis revealed leukocyte esterase and nitrates; urine was obtained for culture. Vaginal metronidazole gel was prescribed. Two days later, the urine culture grew more than 100,000 colony-forming units (CFU) ofEscherichia coliper milliliter and 10,000 to 100,000 CFU ofKlebsiella pneumoniaeper milliliter. A 14-day course of trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole was prescribed. The inguinal swelling reportedly abated, but the flank pain and nausea persisted. Two days after the patient completed the prescribed course of trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole, fever and night sweats developed. After 3 days of fever with a temperature of up to 38.5°C, she began vomiting and subsequently presented to the emergency department of this hospital for evaluation. In the emergency department, the patient reported ongoing flank pain, malaise, nausea, and poor appetite with weight loss of 2.3 kg during the past month. There was no sore throat, cough, or diarrhea. She had a history of hypothyroidism, asthma, bipolar disorder, dysmenorrhea, and migraines. She had had multiple urinary tract infections; pyelonephritis had been diagnosed 4 years before this presentation. A copper intrauterine device had been inserted 6 months before this presentation. Medications included albuterol, budesonide–formoterol, divalproex, levothyroxine, loratadine, and sumatriptan as needed for migraines. The patient did not smoke tobacco, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She had immigrated to the United States from Brazil 1 year earlier; she had been living in New England during the past year and had been working in a laboratory. She had recently spent 3 months in Brazil visiting her husband and had returned to New England shortly before she noted inguinal swelling. While in Brazil, she had remained in a large city and had not visited any remote locations. In New England, she lived alone with one kitten and one full-grown cat. There was no family history of cancer. An aunt had died from tuberculosis, but the patient had had only minimal contact with her aunt. On examination, the temperature was 36.6°C, the blood pressure 100/63 mm Hg, the heart rate 77 beats per minute, the respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute, and the oxygen saturation 100% while the patient was breathing ambient air. The weight was 67.5 kg and the body-mass index (the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters) 24.4. The patient appeared ill. The right side of the abdomen was tender on palpation, without rebound or guarding. Hepatosplenomegaly was not present. Tender bilateral inguinal lymph nodes were noted. No palpable cervical, supraclavicular, infraclavicular, or axillary lymphadenopathy was noted. The remainder of the physical examination was normal. A urine test for human chorionic gonadotropin was negative. Blood levels of glucose, electrolytes, creatine kinase, and lactate dehydrogenase were normal, as were the results of liver-function and kidney-function tests. Blood tests for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) type 1 p24 antigen and antibodies to HIV types 1 and 2 were negative, as was an interferon-γ release assay forMycobacterium tuberculosis. Other laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Imaging studies were obtained. prompt: A 70-year-old man with bipolar disorder was evaluated at this hospital because of depressed mood, suicidal ideation, and gait disturbance. The patient had a long history of depressive episodes, with two previous hospitalizations for suicide attempts. Approximately two decades before the current admission, he was struck on the head with a beam while working at a construction site and had a 4-cm laceration. He presented to the emergency department of this hospital, where the wound was sutured but no further evaluation was conducted. Approximately 10 years before the current admission, around the time of his mother’s death, the patient was evaluated at this hospital because of an episode of irritability, a reduced need for sleep, and grandiosity; he reported feelings of “transcendence” and being “at one with God.” He was admitted for 1 month to the psychiatry unit of a second hospital, where he was treated with lithium and electroconvulsive therapy. Thereafter, he received outpatient psychiatric treatment on a monthly basis, as well as therapy with valproic acid and fluoxetine. Approximately 9 years before the current admission, the patient fell on concrete stairs and had back pain with subsequent lower-leg weakness and urinary incontinence. He was evaluated at a third hospital, where magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbar spine revealed multilevel degenerative changes, including L4–L5 spinal stenosis and central disk protrusion. Acetaminophen and physical therapy were prescribed. Five years later (4 years before the current admission), the patient fell because of an unsteady gait and was evaluated at a fourth hospital. Neurologic examination revealed a memory deficit (with an inability to recall any objects after 5 minutes on the three-item object-recall test) and poor attention (with an inability to perform serial sevens calculations), as well as action tremor in the arms and “mildly unsteady” gait, even with the use of a cane. The remainder of the physical examination was reportedly normal. The complete blood count, results of renal function tests, and levels of electrolytes, valproic acid, folate, vitamin B12, glycated hemoglobin, and thyrotropin were normal; serum and urine toxicologic panels were negative. MRI of the head reportedly revealed no evidence of an infarct, intracranial hemorrhage, or a mass but showed mild prominence of ventricles, sulci, and cisterns. The dose of fluoxetine was decreased, and the patient was discharged 3 days later. Additional falls occurred 2 months and 4 months later, and both times, the patient was evaluated at the fourth hospital. Two months after the most recent fall, he hit the car in front of him while driving. His psychiatrist noted that he had bilateral tremor at rest; the dose of valproic acid was reduced, and he was referred to a neurologist. Two months after the car crash, he fell while walking and was evaluated at the fourth hospital. The evaluation was notable for nystagmus and a normal valproic acid level (89 μg per milliliter; reference range, 50 to 100) despite the dose reduction; the doses of valproic acid and trazodone were reduced, and physical therapy was provided. During the next 5 months, gait instability was reduced but persisted. The patient was evaluated by two other neurologists after reporting a feeling of “imbalance.” Audiometry revealed mild-to-moderate high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Medications were considered to be a contributor to his balance dysfunction. During the next 12 months, the dose of valproic acid was tapered and fluoxetine was stopped; the patient underwent trials of escitalopram and then sertraline for the treatment of depressive symptoms. He reported to his psychiatrist symptoms of confusion, some difficulty with memory, and decreased leg coordination. The Montreal Cognitive Assessment score was 23 (scores range from 0 to 30, with a score of 18 to 25 suggesting mild cognitive impairment). Fifteen months before the current admission, the patient began to have dizziness. MRI of the head (Figure 1), performed at this hospital, revealed an old infarct in the left corona radiata, features of mild small-vessel disease, mild diffuse brain parenchymal volume loss, and mild ventricular prominence. Initial MRI of the Head.An axial fluid-attenuated inversion recovery image (Panel A) and a T2-weighted image (Panel B) show an old lacunar infarct in the left corona radiata (arrowhead), mild scattered hyperintensities suggestive of small-vessel ischemic changes (arrows), and mild generalized brain parenchymal volume loss. Neuropsychiatric testing was performed, and the results did not suggest a neurodegenerative process. Given the patient’s progressively depressed mood, treatment with aripiprazole was started, with the dose adjusted over the following 12 months. Three months before the current admission, the patient reported worsening depression, with hopelessness, guilt, and increased sleep. That month, his son found him unable to walk and requiring assistance to move. On examination, he had tremor and muscle rigidity; on ambulation, he had a shuffling gait and required a cane. Treatment with aripiprazole was stopped, benztropine was started, and sertraline was replaced by fluoxetine. One month before the current admission, the patient was voluntarily hospitalized in the psychiatry unit of this hospital because of worsening depression, which he attributed to the progressive reduction in mobility and strength. He reported 3 weeks of frequent early morning awakenings, anhedonia, low energy, anorexia, difficulty concentrating, and low motivation, such that he had not paid bills or bathed. Examination was notable for tremor, muscle rigidity, and a shuffling gait. Blood levels of folate, vitamin B12, and glycated hemoglobin were normal. Other laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Tests for human immunodeficiency virus types 1 and 2 antibodies and type 1 antigen and for antitreponemal antibodies were negative. Over the 5-day hospitalization, the dose of fluoxetine was increased and treatment with lurasidone was started.
